contributor.username: Just a guy from the KP

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox military person |honorific-prefix = [[Squadron Leader]] |name = Sqn Ldr Beaufort Mosman Hunter Palmer, DFC |honorific-suffix = [[DFC]], [[RAAF]] |birth_date = {{birth-date|df=yes|14 December 1919}} |death_date = {{death-date|df=yes|22 November 2011}} (aged 91) |birth_place = [[Brisbane]], [[Australia]] |death_place = [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]], [[Australia]] |placeofburial= |image = BMH Palmer Menzies Aug1940 Archerfield Bris Formation ex Amberley.jpg |caption = Photograph of Squadron Leader B.M.H. Palmer [[RAAF]] with the [[Prime Minister of Australia]] [[Robert Menzies]] in August 1940 at [[RAAF Station Archerfield]], Brisbane Formation ex Amberley. |nickname = "Beau" |allegiance = Australia |serviceyears = 1940–1945 |rank = [[Squadron Leader]] |branch = [[Royal Australian Air Force]] |commands = [[No. 5 Squadron RAAF]] |unit = |battles = [[Second World War]]
[[Bougainville Campaign]]
[[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]] |awards = [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] |laterwork= }} [[Squadron Leader]] '''Beaufort (Beau) Mosman Hunter Palmer''' {{post-nominals|country=AUS|DFC*}} (14 Dec 1919 – 22 Nov 2011) was an [[Australia|Australian]] recipient of the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)]] and was recognised as one of Australia's finest wartime pilot instructors.{{cite news | last = Coleman | first = Mike | date = | title = Obituary: Beaufort Mosman Hunter Palmer, DFC | url = http://www.couriermail.com.au/ | location = Brisbane | newspaper = The Courier Mail | page = 95 | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = }} ==Early life== Beau was born in [[Toowong]] [[Brisbane]], the son of Carl and Florence (''née'' Robinson), and the grandson of '''Sir [[Arthur Hunter Palmer]]''', {{post-nominals|country=AUS|KCMG}} (28 December 1819 – 20 March 1898) an [[Ireland|Irish]]-Australian politician and a [[Premier of Queensland]]. Beau was educated at [[Brisbane Boys' College]], where he played in the 1st XV and also rowed in two [[Head of the River (Queensland)]] winning crews in 1937 and 1938. He learnt to fly while still at school gaining his pilots wings in 1937 at [[Archerfield Airport]] with the [[Royal Queensland Aero Club]]. ==Military career== Palmer joined the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] in 1938, was [[commissioned officer|commissioned]] and posted to the RAAF Base [[Point Cook, Victoria]] as a flying instructor in 1939. In 1940, Palmer was the first pilot to land at the newly established [[RAAF Station Archerfield]] and also was one of the first pilots to land at the new [[RAAF Base Amberley]] near [[Ipswich]].{{cite web | url = http://www.ozatwar.com/waryrsarch.htm | title = The War Years - Archerfield Airfield | author = | date = | website = Australian War Memorial | publisher = Australian War Memorial | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = Pilot Officer Beaufort Mosman Hunter Palmer was the first pilot to land at the newly established RAAF Archerfield. He landed at Archerfield on about 4 July 1940 six days before the official opening of RAAF Archerfield to deliver a consignment of alcohol for the newly completed officer's club. He then lead his squadron in to land at Archerfield on 10 July 1940 for the official opening of RAAF Archerfield. Beau Palmer later received a Distinguished Flying Cross for an attack on 5 Japanese tanks advancing on Australian troops on Bougainville. Beau Palmer, DFC passed away on 22 November 2011 on the Gold Coast.}}{{cite book | last = Marks | first = Roger | date = 1994 | title = Queensland Airfields WW2 – 50 Years On | url = https://books.google.com.au/books?id=43c-PAAACAAJ | location = Brisbane | publisher = | pages = 276 | isbn = 0646127691 | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = }}{{cite news | last = Lemmon | first = Kate | date = 25 January 2011 | title = Base hitting the heights | url = http://www.qt.com.au/news/base-hitting-the-heights-raaf-amberley-ipswich/751983/ | location = Ipswich | newspaper = The Queensland Times | page = | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = }}{{cite news | last = Lemmon | first = Kate | date = 17 Jun 2010 | title = Air base still flying high | url = http://www.qt.com.au/news/air-base-still-flying-high-after-70-years-in-regio/558981/ | location = Ipswich | newspaper = The Queensland Times | page = | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = }} Palmer 'pulled every string he could to gain a battlefield posting' and in 1944 assumed Command of [[No. 5 Squadron RAAF]]. The Squadron was operating in Dutch New Guinea and Palmer flew over 100 sorties in 1944 and 1945. He was awarded the DFC on [[Bougainville Island|Bouganville]] where he led an operation that destroyed 3 or 4 Japanese tanks in a [[CAC Boomerang]] fighter. The tanks were sighted by a [[New Zealand]] [[Vought F4U Corsair]] pilot which returned to [[Piva Airfield]]. Squadron Leader Palmer then led other Corsairs to the target and directed the attack.{{cite book | last = Long | first = Gavin Merrick | date = 1963 | title = Australia in the War of 1939-1945: Series One, Army, Volume VII The Final Campaigns | url = https://books.google.com.au/books?id=MYoGAQAAIAAJ | archive-url= https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070075--1-.pdf | archive-date=1963 | location = Adelaide | publisher = The Griffin Press | page = 156 | isbn = 0642993661 | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = A fortnight earlier a few Japanese tanks had been located. A New Zealand Corsair pilot reported having seen enemy tanks at Rurl Bay in the north-east of the Island. Squadron Leader B.M.H. Palmer, commanding No 5 Squadron RAAF led other Corsairs to the target and guided them while they attacked three tanks, all of which they damaged. As a result of this and a later attack two were destroyed but the third was evidently moved away.}}{{cite web | url = https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/items/ACCNUM_LARGE/RCDIG1068972/RCDIG1068972--366-.JPG | title = Award D.F.C. | author = | date = 25 October 1949 | website = Australian War Memorial | publisher = Australian War Memorial | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = }} In other operations Palmer achieved a direct hit on a Japanese hut at the southern end of Bouganville Island and in February and March 1945 supported the attacks at the [[Battle of Tsimba Ridge]].{{cite web | url = http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/68915348 | title = Wirraway Completes Attack | newspaper = The Advocate | location = Burnie | page = 5 | date = 26 Feb 1945 | author = | accessdate= 16 August 2016 | quote = Despite heavy bombing by four R.N.Z.A.F. Corsairs on a concentration of Japanese huts at the southern end of Bougainville Island, it remained for an R.A.A.F. Wirraway to complete the work, said a message from R.A.A.F. Headquarters. The Kiwis were led in by Squadron Leader Beau Palmer, of Brisbane, Queensland, in a Wirraway, with Flying Officer F. Meadows, of Mount Lawley, W.A., as observer. They blasted the area with bombs. After the smoke had cleared, Squadron Leader Palmer flew down to observe the damage. To his surprise a hut 60 ft. by 20 ft. had survived the attack, the rest being demolished. He had a phosphorus bomb, usually used to indicate targets, so came down to 50 ft., and let it go as a parting gesture to the Japs. It was a direct hit, the hut immediately catching fire and blazing for 20 minutes.}}{{cite web | url = https://www.awm.gov.au/unit/U59370/ | title = No. 5 Squadron | website = Australian War Memorial | publisher = Australian War Memorial | location = Canberra | date = | author = | quote = From Torokina in Bougainville, the unit undertook tactical reconnaissance, led a strike on Japanese positions by RNZAF Corsairs, and made an attack on enemy positions at Pearl Ridge in support of an army assault. In February and March 1945 an attack was made on positions at Tsimba Ridge and against enemy tanks at Ruri Bay. | accessdate= 16 August 2016}}{{cite book | last = Brown | first = Ernest John | date = 2000 | title = The history of 5 RAAF Squadron : Boomerang and Wirraway fighters in the Bougainville campaign | url = https://www.awm.gov.au/unit/U59370/ | location = Winmalee N.S.W. | publisher = Blackletter Editorial Services | page = | isbn = | access-date= 16 August 2016 | quote = }}{{cite web | url = https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/OG2266/ | title = AWM Photograph OG2266 | last = Harrison | first = John Thomas | date = 18 February 1945 | website = Australian War Memorial | publisher = Australian War Memorial | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = Torokina, Bouganville Island, Solomon Islands. 1945-02-18. Chief of Air Staff Air Vice-Marshall Jones CB CBE DFC (CENTRE) Inspects pilots of No 5 (Tactical Reconnaissance) Squadron RAAF. 469 Squadron Leader Beau Palmer, Brisbane, QLD, and 53 Group Captain W. L. Hely, Melbourne, VIC (extreme left), introduce their chief to the pilots.}} Palmer's war ended in late May 1945 when he stepped on an old American [[anti-personnel mine]]. His leg was subsequently amputated. {{cite book | author = | others = RAAF Historical Section | year = 1995 | title = Units of the Royal Australian Air Force: A Concise History. Volume 2: Fighter Units | location = Canberra | publisher = Australian Government Publishing Service | isbn = 0-644-42794-9 | page = 18 | url = http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/admin/productfiles/publication/materials/545/volume%202%20-%20fighter%20units_web.pdf | quote = In the period 3-10 May, unit aircraft combined with others in attacks on enemy positions in support of the Army advance and capture of Wewak. The Commanding Officer, Squadron Leader B.M. Palmer, was injured on 29 May 1945 when he trod on an old American anti-personnel mine. | accessdate= 16 August 2016}} ==Post-war career== After two years of medical treatment, Palmer purchased Kareelah, a 200 Ha property at [[Warra]] in the [[Darling Downs]]. Almost 30 years later he regained his wings in the 1970s. In later life Palmer was active with the [[Returned and Services League of Australia]] and contributed to saving [[Toowong Memorial Park]] from development.{{cite web | url = http://toowongrsl.blogspot.com.au/ | title = Squadron Leader | author = | date = 29 March 2011 | website = Toowong RSL Sub Branch | publisher = Toowong RSL Sub Branch | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = }} Palmer died in 2011.{{cite news | author = | date = 10 Feb 1946 | title = Social Pages | url = https://www.myheritage.com/research/collection-10450/sunday-mail-brisbane-qld-feb-10-1946?itemId=26364580&action=showRecord | location = Brisbane | newspaper = Sunday Mail | page = 7 | access-date= 17 August 2016 | quote = Settled in Toowoomba after the War}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Palmer, Beaufort Mosman Hunter}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Royal Australian Air Force personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Australian aviators]] [[Category:Australian World War II pilots]] [[Category:People from Queensland]] [[Category:Recipients of the Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)]] [[Category:Royal Australian Air Force officers]] [[Category:Lists of Australian people by school affiliation]] [[Category:Brisbane-related lists|Brisbane Boys]]
